","erg":[],"campus":{"name":"Kensington"}},"additional_information":"This course is offered as General Education.","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Kensington","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"SCIF1004","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SCIF1004 - Science and the Cinema","description":"

Can you imagine Dennis Quaid, Uma Thurman, Sam Neill or Kate Winslet as scientists? Well Hollywood has, in a series of movies which use real scientific concepts as an integral part of the plot. Often the script writers stretch these concepts beyond the realms of reality to make the movies even more exciting. In this general education online elective you will view a series of movies which deal with a range of scientific issues with accompanying lectures to help you understand the concepts.


Movies you will watch include Gattaca (starring Ethan Hawke, Jude Law and Uma Thurman), Jurassic Park (Sam Neill, Jeff Goldblum and Laura Dern), The Day After Tomorrow (Dennis Quaid, Jake Gyllenhaal and Emmy Rossum) and more. So enroll, see some movies and you might learn enough science to create your own genetically modified organism, alternative source of energy, deep space exploration vehicle or help save the world from a cataclysmic disaster.


This course is delivered purely online!

contentlets.description:
Can you imagine Dennis Quaid, Uma Thurman, Sam Neill or Kate Winslet as scientists? Well Hollywood has, in a series of movies which use real scientific concepts as an integral part of the plot. Often the script writers stretch these concepts beyond the realms of reality to make the movies even more exciting. In this general education online elective you will view a series of movies which deal with a range of scientific issues with accompanying lectures to help you understand the concepts.

Movies you will watch include Gattaca (starring Ethan Hawke, Jude Law and Uma Thurman), Jurassic Park (Sam Neill, Jeff Goldblum and Laura Dern), The Day After Tomorrow (Dennis Quaid, Jake Gyllenhaal and Emmy Rossum) and more. So enroll, see some movies and you might learn enough science to create your own genetically modified organism, alternative source of energy, deep space exploration vehicle or help save the world from a cataclysmic disaster.

This course is delivered purely online!

Perspectives in Medical Science","description":"

SCIF1111 introduces students to the skills required by a professional in medical research. The course gives students the opportunity to practise these skills and identify those which may need improvement through their academic career.

contentlets.description:
SCIF1111 introduces students to the skills required by a professional in medical research. The course gives students the opportunity to practise these skills and identify those which may need improvement through their academic career.

The historical and philosophical component of the course provides students with a foundation and origin of current research and practice.
contentlets.title: Perspectives in Medical Science

Introductory Skills for Science","description":"

SCIF1131 provides the opportunity for students to become aware of and develop their professional capabilities. As few great ideas are created in isolation, the connection between like-minded individuals, as well as building on past and present ideas, are the foundation for innovation. Development of these ideas requires collaboration (fitting different pieces together and critical appraisal) and communication for wider awareness. In this course, students will practise teamwork and communication, both as generic skills and within a scientific discipline.

Short theoretical or experimental research project, supervised by a member of academic staff. The internship may encompass project planning, literature review, project development, fieldwork, experimental work, statistical analyses and oral and written reporting. Internships may also involve a placements outside of UNSW, in the form of externally funded research programs. In these cases students will require an academic member of staff to supervise the internship.


Note: Enrolment in this course is by application, and subject to availability of places. Interested students should have identified a potential supervisor and research placement prior to applying.

contentlets.keywords: faculty of science,undergraduate research,science,lab experience,research internship
contentlets.description:
Short theoretical or experimental research project, supervised by a member of academic staff. The internship may encompass project planning, literature review, project development, fieldwork, experimental work, statistical analyses and oral and written reporting. Internships may also involve a placements outside of UNSW, in the form of externally funded research programs. In these cases students will require an academic member of staff to supervise the internship.

Note: Enrolment in this course is by application, and subject to availability of places. Interested students should have identified a potential supervisor and research placement prior to applying.

To apply, download the form at http://www.science.unsw.edu.au/current-students/forms and submit to the Science Student Centre

This course has been developed for students who find a work placement/internship (unpaid or paid) and would like to receive academic credit for the placement. 


This course will enable students to explore and gain a practical understanding of the requirements and expectations of the professional workplace through experiential learning. Students will develop their knowledge, capabilities and employability skills. Internships/work placements enable students to gain practical, supervised experience in the work place.


The course is available to domestic and international students. If a domestic or international student wishes to undertake an overseas work placement, extra conditions will apply before the placement is approved.


Permission to enrol in SCIF2199 will only be granted if the work internship/work placement is compatible to the student's major. Students who wish to enrol must have successfully completed a minimum of 48 UoC and have a WAM of >65 with no more than 1 fail.


Placements are to be a minimum of 3 weeks full-time (105 hours or more). This may be done intensively in the semester break or spread out over the semester as approximately 10 hours per week.


The course will count as a Science elective and is non-graded - this course is satisfactory/unsatisfactory completion.


Note: To enrol in SCIF2199 please contact the [http://www.science.unsw.edu.au/current-students/science-student-centre | Science Student Centre].

This course offers an introduction to concepts and tools necessary for understanding the challenges of sustainable development in the transport-environment-tourism nexus. Students will develop skills in comprehending and assessing the environmental, social and economic sustainability of societal decisions in the context of tourism. A field excursion to Lady Elliott Island – located in the Southern tip of the Great Barrier Reef - will be undertaken with the objective of allowing students to develop an understanding of these societal trade-offs. The field-based learning will emphasise teamwork, as well as independent observational and enquiry skills using remote eco-resort as a context. Topics will include issues at the interface of transport and tourism management and sustainable development principles. Students will engage in preparatory learning leading up to the excursion, as well as reflective learning through assignments during- and post-trip. Around 24 hours of class, including education tours, fieldwork and presentations, are delivered on the island during the field excursion. This is a summer intensive course. Students should be aware that additional costs associated with the field trip will be incurred including return airfare to Lady Elliott Island (LEI), accommodation and food. This course is also available as AVIA3900.

This course introduces you to how science is communicated in a range of settings, to a range of audiences and in a range of formats. You will examine key frameworks and methods of communication and apply them to effectively communicate and represent science in various contexts. Learning activities and assessments will be integrated through case studies featuring models of science communication and strategies for creating effective pieces of communication in line with the themes of the case studies.

Leading Science for Impact","description":"

Leading Science for Impact is designed for professionals who seek to influence and lead social and environmental change using science. Grounded in scientific thinking, social impact methods and decision making, this course aims to equip students with essential knowledge and practical skills to create positive change to enhance social and environmental sustainability.  You will learn about how different forms of knowledge are used to inform change, ethical questions that emerge in knowledge translation and social change, local and global trends impacting science in society, policy processes and decision making. In addition, students will develop their knowledge of the how achieve political and social influence.  In doing so, they will gain practical skills in translating research and, where appropriate, commercialisation. Learning activities will link to real-life contexts and support your professional development.

This course deals with the foundational knowledge about scientific research methods and statistics in scientific professional practice. It aims to enable science professionals to develop systematic, critical and analytical scientific thinking to engage with research and draw on the research literature to inform their practice. You will learn to perform basic statistical analysis procedures, draw defensible conclusions and assess the validity of conclusions based on statistical analysis of experimental data. You will be able to develop your critical thinking through examining the design and execution of experiments, critiquing the analysis and interpretation of results, scrutinising and evaluating published research, and discriminating between evidence-based information and pseudoscience.

This course aims to provide students with theories and best practice models to support them in becoming a global scientist and an equitable leader. You will learn about globalisation and scientific contributions to sustainable global development and active global engagement. You will also learn about principles underpinning equity, diversity and inclusion in a local and global science context and apply them to foster an equitable and inclusive work environment through policies and organisational practice. Learning activities and assessments will be integrated through case studies and real-world scenarios which feature theories, strategies and reflections for equitable and inclusive leadership and practice.

This capstone professional experience project is designed to be undertaken in your own workplace. In this course you will identify an issue arising in your workplace that compromises the quality of the practice or an aspect of the practice that would benefit from improvement. You will then research for strategies to tackle the issue and/or improve the practice and assess these strategies in a relevant professional context using a recognised framework or a self-created framework informed by the relevant literature. Based on your assessment, you will design an innovation, implement the innovation, evaluate the effectiveness and efficacy of the innovation in the professional practice context and report on the innovation. As a requirement of this course, you will nominate a colleague who will act as a critical friend to provide you with feedback and support during your innovation project. This course aims to integrate your leadership capabilities, professional skills and technical expertise in designing, implementing and evaluating innovations for enhancement of professional practice.

Note: Students should enrol in this course over two consecutive terms for a total of 12UoC.

This capstone professional experience project focuses on applied research and is linked with external agencies, industries and businesses who provide real-world projects to teams of students to work on. The projects will present a real-world problem and require you to collaborate in your team to solve it virtually, in an online learning environment. This course will enable you to integrate your leadership capabilities, professional skills and technical expertise into a meaningful experience that will consolidate and extend your learning in the program. External industry partners and UNSW Alumni will act as critical friends to provide you with feedback during your project. They will contribute expertise as part of your online learning community both synchronously and asynchronously.

Note: Students should enrol in this course over two consecutive terms for a total of 12UoC
